title: First minister
text:
A first minister is any of a variety of leaders of government <a href="Cabinet%20%28government%29">cabinet</a>s. The title of "first minister" is currently used to refer to the political leader of a devolved national government, such as the <a href="Devolution%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">devolved administrations</a> of <a href="First%20Minister%20of%20Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="First%20Minister%20of%20Wales">Wales</a>, and <a href="Executive%20Office%20%28Northern%20Ireland%29">Northern Ireland</a>, or of a dependent territory.
Canada.
In <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, a first minister is any of the Canadian first <a href="Minister%20of%20the%20Crown">ministers of the Crown</a>, otherwise known as <a href="Head%20of%20Government">heads of government</a>, including the <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada">Prime Minister of Canada</a> and the <a href="Provinces%20and%20territories%20of%20Canada">provincial and territorial</a> <a href="premier">premier</a>s. The title is used in such formulae as "<a href="first%20ministers%27%20meetings">first ministers' meetings</a>".
In <a href="Newfoundland%20and%20Labrador">Newfoundland and Labrador</a>, the <a href="Inuit">Inuit</a> self-governing region of <a href="Nunatsiavut">Nunatsiavut</a> provides for a <a href="First%20Minister%20of%20Nunatsiavut">first minister</a> responsible to the Nunatsiavut Assembly.
Norway.
The <a href="head%20of%20government%20of%20Norway">head of government of Norway</a> was called "first minister" () between 1814 and 1873, while it was in <a href="personal%20union">personal union</a> <a href="Union%20between%20Sweden%20and%20Norway">with Sweden</a>. In 1893, 12 years prior to the <a href="Dissolution%20of%20the%20union%20between%20Norway%20and%20Sweden%20in%201905">dissolution of the union</a>, it was changed to <a href="prime%20minister">prime minister</a> ("statsminister").
United Kingdom.
In the United Kingdom, the term "first minister" was once used interchangeably with <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">prime minister</a>, such as when <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> stated: "I did not become His Majesty's First Minister so that I might oversee the liquidation of the British Empire!"
Nowadays, the term is used to describe the leaders of the <a href="Devolution%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">devolved</a> governments of <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>. See
Other.
In <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, the <a href="Premiers%20and%20chief%20ministers%20of%20the%20Australian%20states%20and%20territories">premiers and chief ministers</a> are the first ministers of the <a href="Australian%20states%20and%20territories">states and territories</a> respectively.
In <a href="Germany">Germany</a>, the first minister in each federal state is known as the <a href="Minister%20President">Minister President</a> ("Ministerpräsident").
In <a href="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, the first minister for each state with a Malay ruler is known as the <a href="Menteri%20Besar">Menteri Besar</a>. Meanwhile, the heads of government in the four states without a monarch are called <a href="chief%20minister">chief minister</a>s.
<a href="George%20Cadle%20Price">George Price</a> held the office of First Minister of <a href="British%20Honduras">British Honduras</a> from 1961 until 1964, when it became self-governing and the title was changed to <a href="Premier">Premier</a>. He continued as Premier after the <a href="colony">colony</a> changed its names to <a href="Belize">Belize</a>, and then as <a href="Prime%20Minister">Prime Minister</a> after Belize gained full independence in 1981.
